title: Chief of Defence Force (Singapore)
text:
The chief of Defence Force is the head of the <a href="Singapore%20Armed%20Forces">Singapore Armed Forces</a> (SAF), who holds the rank of a <a href="3%20star%20rank">three-star</a> general or admiral.
The position was created in 1974 as the Chief of the General Staff with the appointment of <a href="Winston%20Choo">Winston Choo</a>, and changed to its current name in May 1990. Prior to the appointment of Choo as Chief of the General Staff, the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Defence%20%28Singapore%29">Ministry of Defence</a> (and before it, the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Interior%20and%20Defence">Ministry of Interior and Defence</a>) was in charge of the SAF. Before the position was created, the head of Singapore's army—which at that time made up the military—held the position of Director, General Staff.
The <a href="President%20of%20Singapore">president</a> has the power to appoint each new CDF (as well as new heads of each of the three services in the SAF) on the advice of the <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Singapore">prime minister</a>, who in turn must consult with the <a href="Singapore%20Armed%20Forces%23Legislation">Armed Forces Council</a>, on which the CDF sits. The CDF also maintains a role as an aide-de-camp to the president.
Role.
The CDF is the operational head of the SAF, and holds a seat on the Armed Forces Council which oversees all matters pertaining to the SAF. In addition, if any of the three service chiefs—the Chief of Army, Chief of Navy or Chief of Air Force—is unable to carry out his duties, the CDF is tasked to perform those duties in addition to his own. If the CDF is unable to perform his own duties, the Minister of Defence is allowed to select one of the three service chiefs to perform the CDF's duties.
The office of CDF also carries with it a position as one of three full-time <a href="aide-de-camp">aides-de-camp</a> to the President. According to the Singapore Presidential Office website, the position entails handling the President's security and his/her social needs, in addition to other general duties.
A number of powers relating to <a href="summary%20%28law%29">summary trial</a>s for military offences is vested in the CDF. Paragraph 2, Section 62 of the Singapore Armed Forces Act states that any offence in which the accused holds the <a href="Singapore%20Armed%20Forces%20ranks">rank</a> of Colonel or Military Expert 7 is to be referred to the CDF, who can then dismiss the charge, hold a summary trial, or pass the case on to the director of legal services of the SAF, who can in turn instruct the CDF to try the accused.
As head of the SAF, the CDF often makes visits to countries with shared military interests, such as Bahrain, Japan, and Vietnam, and also occasionally hosts foreign military chiefs on official visits.
List of officeholders (1965–1990).
The role of the head of the SAF was first titled as "Director, General Staff" around 1969, and was held by Brigadier-General <a href="T.%20J.%20D.%20Campbell%20%28brigadier%29">T. J. D. Campbell</a>, who was previously the head of the Singapore Defence Force (1965-1966) and the <a href="Singapore%20Volunteer%20Corps">Singapore Volunteer Corps</a> (late 1950s-1965) before Singapore gained independence in 1965. Campbell had been the acting director since around 1968. <a href="Colonel">Colonel</a> <a href="Kirpa%20Ram%20Vij">Kirpa Ram Vij</a> was appointed his successor. According to sources, the position of "Director, General Staff" was considered similar to the position of the present-day CDF, and was equivalent to the head of army. A news report from "<a href="The%20Straits%20Times">The Straits Times</a>" on Campbell's death refers to him as having been "army chief".
In 1974, Colonel <a href="Winston%20Choo">Winston Choo</a> was given the appointment of Chief of the General Staff, having previously been a departmental head at the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Defence%20%28Singapore%29">Ministry of Defence</a> (MINDEF). In May 1990, the position was changed to its current name, with Choo, who had been promoted to Lieutenant-General, still in office. He had been promoted to each of the general ranks in 1974, 1978 and 1988. Choo stepped down in 1992, after 18 years as the head of the SAF.
<a href="Lee%20Kuan%20Yew">Lee Kuan Yew</a>, who was Singapore's Prime Minister in the 1970s, described <a href="Goh%20Keng%20Swee">Goh Keng Swee</a> as the "de facto" armed forces chief of staff when the latter was Minister of Defence. Goh had been responsible for evolving the SAF while serving as Minister of Defence from 1965–1967.
Although Campbell and Vij have both held a position of similar authority, Choo is referred to as the first CDF in a number of MINDEF publications.
In the past, there also existed a Deputy Chief of the General Staff who was tasked to "[work] with troops on the ground", but there is no deputy position for the present-day CDF in the structure of the SAF.
List of chiefs of Defence Force (1990–present).
Since the appointment of CDF was established in 1990, there have been seven holders to the position, beginning with Winston Choo who was already in office as Chief of the General Staff.
